questions.question_text:
A company uses a model-driven app to track customer information and the products that they have purchased.

You must use a Microsoft Word template to generate a warranty report for customers that lists all items that the customer has purchased in the past year. Customers who have not purchased a product in the last year must not receive a warranty report.

You need to select a dataset.

Which type of dataset can you use?

Anyway a "Flow button for mobile" is not a trigger name, it's the label, the real name is "Manually trigger a flow" only available for instant flows, i say instant flows, and executable across Flow mobile app NOT canvas app.

Based on the given answers I think the bets matching answer is "Flow Button" as there is no trigger called Power Apps trigger. I agree with you the best way to do this is to execute the flow within the App using a submit button, but that trigger won't be called PowerApp trigger?

discussion.content:
Flow Button for Mobile - No. Why make the user open up another app (Flow) when they are already in their Canvas App?

Office 365 Outlook - No. This may be used BY the flow to notify Sales, but should not be used as a trigger for the flow.

Common Data Service - No. Cannot assume that the Canvas app uses CDS/Dataverse as its data store. What if it uses Azure SQL or another data source?

Power Apps - Yes. The user is already using a Power Apps Canvas App. Canvas apps can trigger Flows. This is the best place to trigger the Flow because the user is already there.

Selected Answer: B
Since the flow is called from power apps, the trigger is power apps trigger

Somehow similar to one previous question "You have been tasked with creating a canvas app that allows computer technicians to update job cards after client site visits. The app should also allow for the technicians to notify the sales executives instantaneously when clients order service contracts. As soon as the notification is sent, the technician has to be able to enter the service contract specifics.
You create a button flow with user input that includes the Flow button for mobile trigger.
Does the action achieve your objective?
A. Yes, it does
B. No, it does not
If this A, I go with A) Flow button for mobile as it allows me to initiate a flow from a mobile app

Selected Answer: B
The correct answer is B. Power Apps.

To create a flow that can be triggered by a canvas app, you need to use the Power Apps trigger in Power Automate. This trigger allows you to pass parameters from the app to the flow, such as the customer’s name, email, and warranty details. You can then use other actions in the flow to send an email, a Teams message, or an adaptive card to the sales team with the relevant information. The Power Apps trigger also returns a response to the app, such as a confirmation message or an error message.

Selected Answer: B
B. Power Apps

To create a flow that alerts the sales team when a technician records a warranty sale using the canvas app, you should use the Power Apps trigger. This trigger allows you to call the flow directly from your Power Apps canvas app.

When the technician records the warranty details in the app, you can add a button or an action that invokes the flow with the Power Apps trigger. The flow can then send an alert to the sales team through various means, such as sending an email or posting a message in Microsoft Teams.

Selected Answer: A

I am going with a Power Apps Trigger on this one, reason being.
1. The technicians are using a CANVAS APP
2. The technician needs to enter details about the warranty so that the sales people know who the customer is and what product they are referring to.

For a solution, do the following
1. Create a canvas app
2. Add the input required for the technician to record the details
3. Add a button
4. Add a Power Automate action to the button and select PowerApps as the trigger
5. Create a variable for each input
6. Add a create record action, Dataverse, SharePoint (where ever the data should go)
7. Add a Response action
8. Save and close Power Automate 
9. Select the Flow you just created
10. Map each variable in the OnSelect expression to the matching input control
11. Wrap the RunFlow is a Set(response,RunFlow(var1,var2,var3...))
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powerapps/maker/canvas-apps/using-logic-flows
PowerApps(V2) is OK, PowerApps trigger can't delivery input infomation, however, technicians need to record details about warranty.
Option A is the best answer as Power Apps is not a flow as the name implies. we only have PowerApps as a trigger not Power Apps. Pls compare the two

It states you must use the canvas app to alert them. So you must use the canvas app to trigger the flow. The only viable option here then is the Power Apps trigger. Using flow button for mobile is not using the canvas app.

discussion.content:
"Flow Button for mobile" - nonsense, a button can do any action but guess where ;)
"Power Apps" - nonsense, a canvas app IS a power app and not a trigger
"Office 365 Outlook" - nonsense
"CDS" - YES! trigger is the updated cases! - "The technicians update cases at the end of customer site visit"...

Trick question, depending on which portion of the question you focus on, you will have a different but correct answer. The last thing we are told we need to do is, "You need to create a flow to alert sales team". I see the early portion of the question as misdirection.

Office365.SendEmail("abc@def.com","Subject","EmailBody",
{Attachments:AddColumns(Gallery1.Selected.Attachments, "Name", DisplayName, "ContentBytes", Value, "@odata.type", "")})
Terribly structured questions - Logic says Power Apps Trigger, not Flow button. This is not a trigger.

I think the answer is right, just as when you work through the PL-100 Power Automate modules there are some areas that emphasize how buttons on the Power Automate app are useful for alerts. The fact it mentions Canvas App in the question though makes it tricky....

I think there is an underlying distinction of roles here. Technicians are most likely not authorised to create Warranty records as that is a contract and thus a Sales function. The alert is sent along with some details to say what the customer has agreed to purchase and the Sales Team make a follow up call to finalise the contract(creating necessary records). The Flow button is perfect for this activity using a mobile device. It captures a few details and alerts the Sales Team to follow up with the customer. Before Digital transformation, if a client told me they wanted to purchase a warranty I would have to take their details and say "Someone from the Sales Team will call you to set that up". My role did not have permissions to create contracts in the CRM system.

comments.content: Question says "...technicians use the canvas app to immediately alert the sales team, and then the technician records details about the warranty into the app"; so the alert happens before saving the details, the answer should be POWERAPPS.

discussion.content: If the canvas app is using CDS as it's data source you SHOULD use CDS connector 100% when a register get's created/edited. If it's not CDS then a PowerApp trigger it's actually a button so button should be the answer. Poorly written question anyway
PowerApps trigger => https://www.inogic.com/blog/2019/12/interacting-with-power-automate-flows/
The question is poorly worded, to trigger a flow from within PowerApps, you need to select Action | Power Automate, then either create a new flow or link to an existing Power Apps flow.
Power Apss solutions it's the only tyoe if trigger of 4 solutions.

It is written that the technician alerts the sales team and then insert the warranty details... It should be the other way around but... in any case the Flow button is not in the canvas app. I would go for Power apps ...

I would also say Power Apps.
In the question they say that the technicians would use the Canvas App. The Flow Button is triggered from Microsoft Flow app and not the Power Apps

I'd rather go for the CDS option as a trigger. Once the warrantee record is created you can kick off a process to send an email to the sales team or assign the warrantee record or case record to the sales team for them to complete the work.
The answer would be Power Apps

Which type of trigger should you use?
